Graphical abstract This review provides a comprehensive overview of the electrochemical behaviors of iodide in the aqueous zinc batteries, which will promote the effective design of iodine-related electrochemistry. Iodine is widely used in aqueous zinc batteries (ZBs) due to its abundant resources, low cost, and active redox reactions. In addition to the active material in zinc-iodine batteries, iodine also plays an important role in other ZBs, such as regulating the electrochemical behavior of zinc ions, promoting the reaction kinetic and reversibility of other redox pairs, catalytic behaviors related to iodine reactions, coupling with other halogen ions, shuttle behaviors of polyiodides, etc. However, there is currently a lack of comprehensive discussion on these aspects. Here, this review provides a comprehensive overview of the electrochemical behaviors of iodide in the aqueous ZBs. The effect of iodine ions on the Zn2+ desolvation behaviors and the interfacial behaviors of Zn anode was summarized. Iodine redox pairs boosting other redox pairs, such as MnO2/Mn2+ redox pair and vanadium redox pair to obtain high reversibility and capacity was also discussed. Moreover, the catalytic behaviors related to iodine reactions in aqueous ZBs, synergistic reaction with other halogen ions and suppression of shuttle behaviors for high performance zinc-iodine batteries were systematically analyzed. Finally, future prospects for designing effective iodine electrochemical behaviors with practicability are proposed, which will provide scientific guidance for the practical application of iodine-related aqueous ZBs. Keywords Iodide ion Redox pairs Catalytic behavior Shuttle effect Zinc batteries 1 Introduction Development of clean and safe energy is an inevitable trend to achieve sustainable development in the future. When lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) and lead-acid batteries (LABs) dominate the main energy storage market, the safety of LIBs or the environmental pollution of LABs is causing concern. Flow batteries have good cycling stability, but their usage scenarios are greatly limited. Compared to these systems, aqueous zinc batteries (ZBs) have received widespread attention due to the low cost, high safety and environmental-friendly [1]. Iodine has the advantages of abundant reserves and active redox potential, which is widely used as an electrode or electrolyte functional additive in aqueous ZBs [2]. Although iodine has a higher atomic mass than bromine and chlorine, it still has a special advantage in regulating battery behavior. The rapid redox reaction kinetics of iodine is helpful to improve the ratio performance of the battery. The polyvalent characteristic of iodine makes the battery realize multi-electron transfer in the process of charging and discharging. The wide electrochemical window of iodine-based battery makes the battery more flexible in the adjustment of potential changes during charging and discharging. Therefore, in recent years, a series of advances have been made (Fig. 1 ), including effect of iodine on the behavior of zinc ions [3], iodine redox pairs coupled with other redox pairs [4], catalytic behaviors related to iodine reactions [5], iodine ion coupled with other halogen ions [6], shuttle behaviors of polyiodides in zinc-iodine batteries [7], etc. Notably, the stability and safety of iodine or iodine complex have led to their development in zinc battery systems. For example, iodine ions can assist in the reversible Zn deposition in aqueous electrolytes [8]; Iodine exhibits redox pair at high operating voltages and improved kinetics [9]; Catalytic behaviors of iodine species promote reaction kinetics of other redox pairs [10]. However, the electrochemical behaviors of iodine species still face many challenges. On the one hand, the shuttle effect of polyiodide ions and the subsequent interfacial electron transfer can cause self-discharge and deteriorate the Coulombic efficiencies (CEs) of the battery. The current inhibition strategies focus on anchor by various carbon materials [11], membranes as well as coating layers [12], catalysis by monatomic materials [13], and additives in the electrolyte [14]. On the other hand, the understanding of function mechanisms of electrochemical and catalytic behaviors is not clear and comprehensive enough. These include how iodine redox pair works in synergy with other redox pairs or other halogen ions; how the catalytic behaviors of iodine affect the reaction kinetic and cycling stability of cathode materials in ZBs. In addition, iodine ion electrolyte additives have a significant impact on the deposition behavior and morphology evolution of Zn anode. Further enhancing their electrochemical performance will have broad application prospects in large-scale electrical energy storage (EES) for the electricity grid, household energy storage, and uninterrupted power supply. Although many reviews focus on zinc-iodine batteries [15,16], they mainly focus on the shuttle effect, slow reaction kinetics, unstable cathode materials and other problems faced by zinc-iodine batteries. At present, there is a lack of comprehensive discussion on the electrochemical behavior of iodine in aqueous ZBs. Herein, the iodine electrochemical behaviors not only in zinc-iodine batteries, but also in other aqueous ZBs were systematically discussed. Table 1 summarizes and compares some of the key performance parameters of iodine action on aqueous ZBs. This review focuses on a comprehensive discussion of the effect of iodine ions on the Zn2+ desolvation behaviors and the interfacial behaviors of Zn anode, iodine redox pairs boosting other redox pairs, catalytic behaviors related to iodine reactions, synergistic reaction with other halogen ions and shuttle behaviors of polyiodides. More importantly, an effective design scheme of practical iodine electrochemical behaviors for iodine-related aqueous ZBs was highlighted. 2 Effect of iodine on the behavior of zinc ions Iodine ions are often used as a functional additive in electrolytes to alter the behavior of zinc ions in zinc metal batteries. In this section, the changes of composition and structure of aqueous zinc battery electrolyte induced by iodide ions are significantly described. The behavior of iodine ions on zinc ions and the effect on the performance of aqueous zinc batteries were revealed. As we all know, rich active water in electrolyte will corrode the zinc anode and reduce the cycle life of battery. The organic co-solvent such as glycol dimethyl ether (DME) was added to electrolyte to reduce the activity of water molecules by disrupting the original hydrogen bonding network of water molecules [20,21]. However, the addition of DME also significantly slowed down the kinetic process of zinc deposition. To address this issue, Zhou et al. [22] introduced a trace iodine ion additive into electrolyte, which could form a negatively charged adsorption layer on the surface of Zn anode (Fig. 2 a). The I− with negative charges are beneficial for adsorbing Zn2+, reducing the desolvation energy of Zn2+ in interfaces. Doubling exchange current density also confirms that the introduction of iodine ions can accelerate the Zn deposition kinetics (Fig. 2b). Introducing other halogen ions such as Br− were also demonstrated to accelerate the Zn/Zn2+ redox reaction process. Yang et al. suggested that the complexation between the Br− and Zn2+ to form ZnBr4 − (Fig. 2c) could overcome the slow interaction kinetics of coordination Zn2+ [23]. During the reaction, Br− can replace one or more H2O molecules from [Zn (H2O)6]2+, which results in low energy barriers during the desolvation of ZnBr(H2O)5 + (Fig. 2d). In the conventional zinc-salt electrolyte, Zn2+ strongly interacts with water molecules, which leads to weakening of the O–H bonds and intensifies the hydrogen evolution reaction on Zn anode [24–26]. The introduction of I− additive can disrupt the original hydrogen bonding network of solvated structure. Zhang et al. demonstrated that I− can transfer electrons into the original Zn2+ solvated structure, in which reducing electron loss from water molecules ensures reduction stability of solvated structure (Fig. 2e) [3]. As an electron donor, I− in ZnI(H2O)5 + can inject electron into both Zn2+ and water molecule, enabling the lower charges of Zn (+0.52) than that in Zn(H2O)6 2+ (+0.56), as shown in Fig. 2f. In addition, the ZnI(H2O)5 + has a higher LUMO energy level than Zn(H2O)6 2+, which endows better ability to resist hydrogen evolution reaction. The introduction of I− into the ZnSO4 electrolyte also enhances the spontaneous reaction by utilizing the redox process between I−/(I3 −/I5 −) to better activate the electrolyte. It also enhances the adsorption of O2 at the electrode to generate additional discharge capacity, which gives the battery a high open circuit voltage and high capacity [27]. The different action mechanisms of iodine ions in ZBs are crucial to the behavior of zinc ions. First of all, the adsorption of iodine ions on solvation can enhance the binding of zinc ions on the electrode surface, reduce the migration and diffusion of zinc ions in the electrolyte. Second, iodine ions can also destroy the interaction between Zn2+ and H2O molecules, inhibit the generation of hydrogen evolution reaction. However, the mechanism of action of iodine ions is also affected by the concentration and composition of the electrolyte. Therefore, reasonable electrolyte design and concentration optimization can maximize the regulatory role of iodine ions in zinc batteries. It should be note that there are certain differences in the role of iodine ions in aqueous batteries and non-aqueous batteries. In aqueous batteries, water is a polar solvent and can form a strong solvation layer with iodine ions through hydrogen bonding. This solvation affects the mobility and diffusion coefficient of iodide ions. In non-aqueous batteries, organic solvents are usually used as electrolytes, and these organic solvents have low polarity. Therefore, the interaction between them and iodine ions is weak, resulting in that the mobility and diffusion coefficient of iodine ions in organic electrolytes may be higher. 3 Iodine redox pairs coupled with other redox pairs Introduction of iodide ion additives can significantly improve the reversibility of other redox pairs, thus enabling the battery to have a high capacity and high operating voltage output. The function of iodide in this aspect was revealed from the two aspects of the action of iodide on aqueous zinc–manganese batteries and zinc-vanadium batteries. 3.1 MnO2/Mn2+ redox pair Iodine redox is facilitate to activate the cathode residue and improve the cathode utilization. Typically, the long-term operation stability of aqueous zinc–manganese batteries is constrained by incomplete dissolution of MnO2 and exfoliation of thick MnO2 layers [28]. In order to overcome this issue, Lu et al. propose a mediator strategy to facilitate MnO2 dissolution and recover “lost” capacity from exfoliated MnO2 [29]. As shown in Fig. 3 a, I− mediator chemically reduces dead MnO2 to form Mn2+ during discharging, and itself was oxidized to tri-iodide (I3 −). After discharging, tri-iodide can get reduced at the electrode returning to I−, finishing one mediation cycle. The working principle of using iodine as an oxidation–reduction mediator strategy was verified by UV–vis spectra (Fig. 3b). After adding MnO2 solid into the KI solution, the I− (227 nm) absorbance decreases along with the increase of two absorbance peaks at 289 nm and 351 nm, which can be attributed to I3 −, confirming the reaction between I− and MnO2 forming I3 −. Interestingly, the signal peaks of I3 − disappeared after discharging, indicating the reproduction of I− mediator. The functional role of I− mediator in aqueous zinc–manganese batteries has been further confirmed by Zheng et al. [4]. The residue of MnO2 with poor conductivity exacerbated the MnO2/Mn2+ hysteresis. After the addition of I− to the electrolyte, the MnO2 can be effectively reduced to Mn2+ (Fig. 3c). The reason is that the I3 −/I− reaction reduces the residual MnO2 during the discharge process to maintain the activity of the cathode. This was confirmed by the fact that the oxidation potential of I3 −/I− was lower than the reduction potential of MnO2/Mn2+ (Fig. 3d). The discharge voltage of the Zn-MnO2/I2 battery was much higher than that of the Zn-MnO2 battery [4]. The I3 −/I− reaction also contributes additional area capacity, leading to an increase in the discharge capacity of the battery. Since Br− and I− are in the same halogen group, which have similar features, Br− was also revealed as a redox mediator in zinc-manganese batteries [30]. As shown in Fig. 3e, MnO2 deposited around the cathode is dissolved by the redox process of Br−/Br3 − during the discharge process. The oxidation potential of Br3 −/Br− reaction shows lower than that of MnO2/Mn2+ reaction (Fig. 3f). The reduction potential of zinc-manganese cells in the presence of Br− is similar to that in the presence of I−, which confirms that Br− can also promote the dissolution of residual MnO2. The charging and discharging curves of MnO2/Br2-Zn and MnO2-Zn cells show that the MnO2/Mn2+ reaction kinetics were effectively enhanced. In addition, the occurrence of Br3 −/Br− reaction on the cathode can further reduce the amount of solid MnO2 deposited on the carbon felt, and improve the reversibility of the MnO2/Mn2+ reaction. 3.2 Vanadium redox pair Introducing iodine redox mediator to increase the capacity of other ZBs such as zinc-vanadium batteries was also proposed [9]. In a typical case, Zn(CF3SO3)2 and ZnI2 were introduced into the electrolyte to construct a binary ionic electrolyte containing Zn2+ and I−. With the embedding/de-embedding process of Zn2+, a shift in the valence state of vanadium in the NH4V4O10 cathode is induced, causing a transfer of electrons [31]. Meanwhile, the porous activated carbon complex (PAC) in the electrode has a large surface area, which can rapidly adsorb I− in the electrolyte to achieve I−/I2 conversion (Fig. 4 a). With the assistance of ethylene glycol, Zn2+ and Ⅰ− bipyramidal ions can be simultaneously and continuously de-embedded and reversibly desorbed in vanadium-based cathode materials. Thus, a higher capacity is obtained through the redox process of iodine compared to the bare vanadium redox pair. As shown in CV curves in different electrolytes (Fig. 4b), independent Zn2+ intercalation and irreversible iodine redox were detected in Zn2+-only (3Zn2+-00–90) and I−-only (0-02KI-90) electrolytes, respectively. In the binary ionic electrolyte containing Zn2+ and I− (3Zn2+-01KI-90), there is a highly reversible and continuous Zn2+ intercalation in the low-voltage region and iodine redox in the high-voltage region. CV curves showed that the high voltage property of iodine can lead to an increase in the operating voltage and capacity of zinc-vanadium batteries. Therefore, the interaction between the iodine redox pair and the vanadium redox pair is very important for the battery charging and discharging process. The migration of iodine ions between the cathode and anode electrodes provides the necessary electron exchange for the redox reaction of vanadium ions, ensuring the efficient operation of the battery. In summary, the redox pair of iodine can significantly improve the reversibility of other redox pairs in the coupling process. Thus, the battery has a high capacity and a high working voltage output. However, there are some problems in the process of coupling. First, the dissolution of iodine may lead to a deterioration in battery performance. In addition, the structure of vanadium/manganese oxide may change during charging and discharging, which affects the long-term stability of the battery. To overcome these problems, researchers should pay more attention to optimizing the composition of the electrolyte and designing novel electrode structures. 4 Catalytic behaviors related to iodine reactions In ZBs, catalysts play a crucial role. In this section, the effect of catalyst on the performance of ZBs will be elaborated from two aspects. The first aspect is to discuss the catalytic action of iodide ions in other aqueous ZB systems. The second aspect is to discuss the influence of carrier materials (non-metallic carrier materials and metal carrier materials) on the performance of zinc-iodine batteries. 4.1 Catalytic behaviors of iodine ions Due to the agile redox properties of iodine, it often plays an important role as catalysis to promote other redox reactions in aqueous ZBs. Iodide ions can promote the reduction reaction of zinc ions and reduce the deposition potential of zinc ions. Song et al. [32] combined iodine as a catalyst with porous carbon to obtain high-loading zinc benzoquinone batteries. In this case, I2 acts as a transformation medium that reacts with Zn2+ and BQ (benzoquinone molecule) to form ZnBQ and I−. Then I− with I2 to form I3 − during the discharge process. During charging, ZnBQ reacted with I3 − to form I− and BQ (Fig. 5 a). It can be seen that the introduction of I2 effectively accelerates the transport process of Zn2+, reducing the reaction barrier between BQ and BQ2−. Iodine is also used to improve the efficiency and reversible reaction of conversion-type electrodes. In zinc-bismuth battery, the introduced iodide ions can effectively activate the Bi-O bond and improve the reaction kinetics of Bi2O3 in the discharge process (Fig. 5b) [33]. At the same time, I− forms BiOI instead of Bi2O3 with Bi3+, thus changing the intermediate reaction step. In addition, the reaction of Bi3+ with H2O was avoided due to the preferential coordination of I− with Bi3+. The reaction produces soluble Bi-I compounds rather than direct solid-phase passivation products, reducing the accumulation of dead trivalent Bi on the electrodes (Fig. 5c). Thus, the rate performance and cycle stability of the battery are enhanced. The I− catalyst could also promote the oxidation process of ZnS/S8 (Fig. 5d). The specific mechanism is due to the fact that when I− is adsorbed on the surface of ZnS nanoparticles, it leads to the atomic rearrangement of ZnS, and the Zn-S interaction is weakened. This promotes the electrochemical reversible oxidation reaction from ZnS to S (Fig. 5e) [10]. In summary, the catalytic action of iodine ions can promote the transport process of Zn2+ and accelerate the redox reaction process of the whole system. It can reduce the accumulation of cathode products and improve the utilization rate of cathode. The coulomb efficiency and cycle stability of the battery are also improved. 4.2 Effect of carrier catalysts on the behavior of iodide ions 4.2.1 Non-metallic carrier catalysts According to the literatures, the addition of an electrocatalyst can effectively reduce the iodine/polyiodide reaction energy barrier [34], solve the reversibility of iodine anodes [34], unlock the utilization of iodine electrodes [34], Thus, rapid conversion kinetics and stable conversion reaction of active iodine are achieved. It was reported that the catalytic performance of the carrier material is often linked to the nitrogen species. Graphitic nitrogen was confirmed to have excellent catalytic properties, which can accelerate the kinetics of redox reactions and inhibit the production of polyiodide ions [35]. The strong catalytic activity of graphite nitrogen is the fundamental reason for the nitrogen-doped porous carbon that leads to the direct conversion of I2 to I−. Fig. 6 a illustrates the mechanism of understanding the interfacial redox reaction from I2 to I− based on Fe2N cluster [36]. Electrochemical kinetics can be governed by sufficient binding affinity for iodine species and effective charge transfer at liquid–solid boundaries. Specifically, the hierarchical porous structure will enhance the ability of iodine to accommodate in physically confined spaces. The chemical interaction between nitrogen doping and Fe2N will further enhance the accommodation of iodine. The exposed Fe2N clusters on the surface will endow strong chemical adsorption ability to suppress shuttle effect. In addition, the integrated conductivity will enhance the rapid electron transfer of reversible redox reaction of iodine. The differential charge density and charge distribution further demonstrate the charge transfer between the substrate and iodine (Fig. 6b). The polarity enhanced N-graphene Fe2N clusters significantly promote charge transfer between the substrate and iodine, which will further accelerate the redox conversion of iodine. In-situ Raman was further conducted to monitor the charging/discharging process of iodine conversion. As shown in Fig. 6c, weakened peaks of intermediates (I5 − and I3 −) were observed in PC@Fe2N-4/I2 electrode, suggesting the direct redox reaction from I2 to I−. In contrast, PC@Fe2N-0/I2 electrode still shows a strong polyiodide peak of I5 − and I3 −, indicating slow reversible conversion kinetics of iodine. The result reveals the Fe2N clusters are beneficial to reversible redox reactions with the suppression of polyiodide intermediates. Also based on graphite-nitrogen, Wang et al. [37] proposed a HC@FeNC material. Among them, Fe-N4 sites can produce enhanced physico-chemical interactions with polyiodides. At the same time, the microporous structure of porous carbon also plays a certain role in confining iodide ions. Most critically, the Fe-N4 site reduces the Gibbs free energy in the iodine conversion reaction and promotes the complete transformation of I−→I0, compared to the I−→I3 − conversion that is common in most zinc-iodine batteries. IL-ZIF-90 with abundant nitrogen species has been proven to be an excellent catalyst for iodine conversion. As shown in Fig. 6d, the four adsorption sites (A, B, C, and D) are located directly above pyridine N, pyrrole N, N with lone pair electrons, and N with positive charge (pyridine N), respectively. The Coulomb interactions between positively charged nitrogen and negatively charged iodine in the nitrogen species in IL-ZIF-90 were utilized to effectively reduce iodine leakage. To reveal the potential mechanism, density functional theory (DFT) was conducted to explore the adsorption behavior of these four N sites on the IL-ZIF-90 cathode. The calculated negative ΔG values of the four N sites suggest that the reduction step of I2 to I− is spontaneous. The reduction reaction from I3 − intermediate product to the final product I− is the rate-determining step. Generally, a low ΔG value indicates a rapid response rate. Fig. 6d shows that the lower ΔG values of site C (−1.68 eV) and site D (−1.84 eV) for rate-determining step demonstrate the favorable polyiodide conversion. The rapid redox kinetics of IL-ZIF-90 is due to the strong Lewis acid-base interaction between nitrogen with lone pair electrons and I2. Hu et al. [38] recently proposed an antiprotein-structured Co9S8@NC composite catalyst. Due to the heterogeneous interface between Co9S8 and the substrate NC with different working functions, the electrons of Co9S8 with higher Fermi level will spontaneously transfer to the substrate NC with lower Fermi level, and the charge-deficient state formed can effectively adsorb I−. At the same time, the activation energy of the cascade I+/I0/I− electrode is reduced by the high specific surface area, which further promotes the double electron transfer process of iodine. 4.2.2 Metal carrier catalysts Metal atom catalysts have high atom utilization and separate active sites. In recent years, they have been used by many researchers in the study and utilization of battery catalysts [39–41]. Ma et al. prepared a Ni single atom embedded hierarchical porous carbon framework (NiSAs-HPC) [42], which can efficiently restrict polyiodides in framework and suppress the shuttling during cycling, as shown in Fig. 7 a. More importantly, the NiSAs can promote rapid redox reaction from I2 to I− via an electrocatalytic effect (Fig. 7b). The in-situ Raman spectra of Zn–I2 batteries was also conducted to confirm the function of NiSAs. Compared to the HPC/I2 cathode, the peaks associated with I3 − and I5 − were inapparent during discharging and charging in NiSAs-HPC/I2 cathode (Fig. 7c), suggesting the rapid conversions of polyiodides efficiently. Traditional activated carbon (AC) with good electrical conductivity is generally used as insulating active I2 host, but the sluggish reaction kinetics, low active I2 utilization and severe shuttle effects prevent the stable high-energy zinc iodine batteries (Fig. 7d). The mesoporous carbon with abundant pores can physically confine active I2, generating I3 − intermediates and alleviating I3 − shuttle effect. However, it is also affected by slow redox kinetics and corrosion of Zn anode. Single atom catalysts (SACs) with activated metal atoms provide optimal utilization of catalytic sites for reactions. Yang et al. explored a Fe SAC on mesoporous nitrogen doped carbon (Fe SAC-MNC) [34], which presents many benefits for Zn||I2 batteries. Firstly, mesoporous nitrogen doped carbon has excellent electronic/ionic conductivity, which enables effective physical/chemical adsorption of iodine/polyiodine. SAC-MNC with Fe SACs can reduce the activation energy barrier of I2 reduction reaction and accelerate the iodine/polyiodide reaction. By catalyzing the reversible oxidation–reduction of I−/I2 and I2/I+ and promoting the conversion of polyiodide intermediates, the high iodine utilization rate and long cycle life of zinc iodide batteries have been enhanced [34]. Due to the effectiveness of metal single atoms, Guo et al. studied the interaction between a series of SACs and iodine species to select appropriate SACs to reduce or eliminate shuttle effects [43]. According to DFT calculations, SACs such as Cu in the N4-metal structure are favorable for the adsorption of I2 (Fig. 7e). It also shows that the lowest energy barrier for I2 reduction and oxidation reactions is located at the Cu site. Cu SAC is advantageous for reducing I2 to I− and exhibit a low energy barrier for releasing I− from surface, thus enabling faster conversion kinetics compared to other SACs. Liu et al. [44] proposed that the orbital hybridization effect between the d orbitals of Fe atoms doped in the positive carrier and the P orbitals of iodides (I2 and ICl) could significantly enhance the substrate’s adsorption of iodides. The hydrolysis reaction of I+ is inhibited and the four-electron transfer process of I−/I0/I+ is accelerated. The resulting battery has a high area capacity (3mAh cm−2). In summary, the metal atom catalysts can be used as the active center to promote the redox reaction process of iodine and accelerate electron transfer, so as to improve the charge and discharge rate and rate performance of zinc batteries. Secondly, the metal atom catalyst can also make the positive electrode have a unique pore structure and high specific surface area, and improve the adsorption capacity of iodine. Thus, the shuttle behavior of polyiodide ions can be effectively inhibited and the cycle stability of the battery can be improved. 5 Iodine ion coupled with other halogen ions In most zinc iodine batteries, although the electron transfer process of iodine is complete, it is limited to the I−/I0 reaction, while the I0/I+ reaction is difficult. By coupling with other halogen ions, the valence state of iodine is changed to achieve the process of multi-electron transfer, which can obtain high capacity and high voltage platform. In addition, it can also inhibit the dissolution of iodine and the transfer of polyiodide. In this section, the effects of other halogen ions on the behavior of iodide ions are mainly divided into two types. The first type is the introduction of bromide ions into the electrolyte. For example, Wang et al. [6] achieved I− activation from I0 to I+ by introducing Br− as an activator. The capacity of the cell was increased via stabilizing the I−/I+ four-electron reaction process (Fig. 8 a). The valence state of Br does not change during this process. It serves to promote further oxidation of I− to a higher valence state while forming I2Br− as intermediate state, and then I was further oxidized to I+, in which Br− stabilize I+ in the form of IBr2 − (Fig. 8b). It should be noted that it is difficult for iodine ions to transition from I− to I+ without a medium. The capacity of the obtained cell was made much higher than that of the two-electron zinc-iodine cell. Br− can also serve as a complexing agent in electrolyte. According to Fig. 8c, during charging process, Br− in the electrolyte complexes with I− to form I2Br−, and zinc ions are reduced to metal at the anode. Free iodine is stabilized by forming I2Br− with free bromine (Fig. 8d). Meanwhile, both I2Br− and I3 − have linear trihalide structure (Fig. 8e), which has been proven to achieve the release of I− and inhibition of side reactions [45]. Halogen ions can also form specific internal conjugates with iodines. When introducing a rich Br− additive, a 12-electron transfer system was constructed via the internal conjugate formed between I2 and Br−. During the charging process, bromide exists in the form of IBr, while generating I+, promoting the conversion of iodine to iodate. During the discharge process, iodate is reduced to IBr and Br2. Through this mechanism, the Br−-IO3 − cycle was achieved. The Br−/Br2 reaction process accelerates the oxidation–reduction on the I−/IO3 − electrode, which enhances the reaction kinetics of iodide conversion [46]. The second type is the introduction of chloride ions into the electrolyte. For example, the researchers found that Cl− can react with the resulting I3 − to ICl with I− [47]. There is a reversibility of the generation/disappearance process of the ICl during the charging/discharging process. This leads to the appearance of a four-electron transfer process in the I−/I0/I+ redox process with high reversibility and capacity. Some researchers have also proposed introducing ZnCl2 into electrolytes containing iodide to reduce free iodide ions in the solution, and inhibiting their reaction with I2 to form I3 −/I5 − by reacting Cl− with I− to form complexes [48]. Compared to the standard hydrogen electrode (SHE), the redox potential is only 0.54 V. This results in a low voltage plateau for zinc iodine batteries (Fig. 8f). To this end, Li et al. [49] found that free Cl− acts like a ladder to activate and stabilize the I0/I− redox process at high potentials (Fig. 8g). It makes the battery have two discharge platforms I−/I0 and I0/I+, and the high platform improves the capacity and energy density of the battery system. When the source of iodine originates from cathode, the chloride ions in the electrolyte can likewise react with the iodine to form ICl3 −. During this process, I− is converted to I0 and then to I+, and the intercalation between I and Cl halides inhibits the solubilization of iodine and the shuttle of polyiodide ions. Wang et al. [50] also proposed an electrolyte additive trimethylamine hydrochloride (TAH) containing Cl− and amine groups. Among them, I+ can form a bidentate coordination structure with Cl− and amine groups at the same time. The hydrolysis reaction of I+ was inhibited. The I−/I2/I+ four-electron transfer process is realized at low concentration. The obtained battery has a specific capacity of nearly 450mAh/g. In summary, the synergistic effect of iodide ions with other halogen ions provides a new strategy for improving the performance of zinc batteries. This process can improve the cycle life and rate performance of zinc batteries by activating the polyvalent conversion reaction of iodine and inhibiting the formation of intermediate product I3 −. 6 Shuttle behaviors of polyiodides and suppression strategies 6.1 Principles and causes of the shuttle effect The shuttle effect refers to the iodine ions shuttling between the cathode and anode electrodes during the operation of the battery (Fig. 9 a), resulting in the loss of active substances and the degradation of battery performance. The shuttle effect in zinc-iodine batteries mainly originates from the structural changes of the electrode material during the electrochemical reaction. During the charging process, the iodine electrode will undergo the de-embedding and embedding of iodine ions. These processes may lead to structural damage and fragmentation of the electrode materials, resulting in the formation of a large number of tiny particles. These particles will be free in the electrolyte, triggering the shuttle effect. Meanwhile, the nature of the electrolyte is also an important factor influencing the generation of iodide ion shuttle effect. Therefore, in this section, the methods to inhibit the shuttle effect of iodine ions are divided into: membrane method, artificial coating, electrolyte modification, carrier material catalysis, and adsorption method. In this way, the action mechanism of various methods is further elaborated systematically. 6.2 Shuttle effect suppression strategies Although the shuttle effect is important, as its strategies have been widely analyzed [2,51], we will briefly discuss them here. For suppressing the shuttling behavior of iodide ions in zinc-iodine batteries, a functional membrane was constructed to block the I3 − shuttle behavior generated at the anode (Fig. 9b) [52,53]. Typically, anion Concentrated Electrolyte (ACE) membranes are rich in sulfonic acid groups and have good mechanical strength. The rich sulfonic acid groups therein can bind with hydrated zinc ions, thus effectively reducing the desolvation energy and guiding Zn2+ ion transport and orderly deposition of zinc ions. Its non-porous nature inhibits the shuttle effect of polyiodide ions while controlling the Zn2+ ion flux on the zinc anode side. The design of multifunctional diaphragms containing the moiety is of great utility and is expected to be further explored in the inhibition of the shuttling process of polyiodide ions [54]. The researchers also prevented the generated polyiodide ions from contacting with Zn anode by constructing an artificial coating on the surface of Zn anode to avoid corrosion (Fig. 9c) [55]. For example, a slurry is prepared by combining a Zn-based zeolite obtained by Zn2+ exchange with a PVDF binder [56]. It is uniformly coated on the surface of Zn anode to obtain a multifunctional protective layer. The ion selectivity of the zeolite material can ensure the rapid and uniform migration of Zn2+ and inhibit the growth of zinc dendrites; it can also effectively hinder the passage of I3 −, inhibiting the self-discharge of battery [7]. CMCS crosslinking gel or covalent organic framework was also proposed as effective coating to inhibit the growth of zinc dendrites and the shuttle effect of iodide ions [57,58]. Inhibiting the shuttle effect of iodide ions by modifying electrolytes has been successively explored because of its simplicity of operation, high efficiency and safety [59–61]. The electrolyte additive can inhibit the shuttle effect of iodide ions by two methods. One method is to directly inhibit the reaction process between I2 and I−; another method is to inhibit the shuttle of polyiodide ions [62–64]. For instance, the [SCN]− additive with strong interactions with I−/I2 prevents the process of I− reacting with I2 to form I3 − (Fig. 9d) [65]. The affinity for the formation of [I2SCN]− complexes between SCN− and I2 is stronger because of the formation of I–S bonds. The SCN− additive also promotes the dissolution of insoluble I2 in deionized water. It avoids the next reaction between I2 and I−. During charging, SCN− can complex with I2 to form [I2SCN]−, releasing 1/3 of I− and preventing I2 precipitation from blocking the pore structure of the electrode [65]. Although I− as a Lewis base is often used as the cationic polymerization inhibitor to prevent some parasitic reactions in batteries [66]. However, when I2 is encountered as Lewis acid, Lewis acid-base interaction will occur, forming a polyiodide chain. Therefore, in the study of zinc-iodine batteries, researchers often use I2 as a Lewis acid to form complexes with Lewis bases (such as some functional groups in electrolyte additives). This Lewis acid-base interaction helps stabilize I2 in the electrolyte and prevents it from unwanted side reactions with I− during battery charging and discharging. For example, certain functional groups containing nitrogen or oxygen, such as amines [52], alcohols [67], or carboxylate [61], can act as Lewis bases to form stable complexes with I2, thus inhibiting the formation of polyiodide ions. Some researchers have also inhibited the shuttle of polyiodide ions by directly or indirectly adjusting the concentration of the electrolyte. The reaction of I− with I2 to form I3 − was inhibited by directly increasing the concentration of ZnSO4 solution (Fig. 9e). The solubility equilibrium of I− with H2O can be effectively shifted to the left. The reason for this is due to the fact that as the concentration of ZnSO4 increases, it makes the decrease of H2O content and the increase of H+ concentration in the solution. This prevents the production of too much I− to react with I2, and thus reducing the shuttle effect of I3 −. At the same time, the activity of free H2O molecules in the electrolyte is inhibited, which also prevents the reaction between H2O and I2, further reducing the dissolution of I2 [68]. Hydrogels have been successively used to study the process of blocking the reaction of I2 with I−. Jin et al. used a heteropoly ionic hydrogel for aqueous zinc-iodine batteries [69]. On the cathode side, the iodophilic polycationic hydrogel allowed iodide ions to aggregate and react with cations, avoiding the reaction of iodide ions with iodine monomers to form polyiodide ions. The shuttle effect was effectively mitigated and the redox kinetics of iodine was promoted [69]. Catalyst plays a crucial role in shuttle effect. In recent years, researchers have found a close correlation between catalysts and the iodide ion shuttle effect [70,71]. On the one hand, catalysts can affect the migration and diffusion of iodide ions, which changes the kinetic of electrochemical reactions. On the other hand, the iodide ion shuttle effect can also affect the activity and stability of the catalyst. Prussian blue (PB) has a three-dimensional open framework, in which cations can be rapidly inserted/extracted through its tunable structure surrounded by cyanide bridges and metal ions (Fig. 9f). More importantly, internal metal ions attached to the ends of the C≡N group can act as catalytic hotspots to modulate the redox of iodine, which shows promise as a functional host. The redox-active iron sites play a decisive role in the catalysis and activation of iodine (electron transfer from iodine to iron) [72]. The I2-loaded oxide salt templated carbon (I2/OSTC) cathode strategy was proposed to obtain a high specific capacity and 10,000 stable cycles [67]. The synergistic effect of abundant oxygen-containing functional groups on the surface of OSTC and the physical constraints of the nanoscale porous structure of the OSTC matrix enhance the binding of iodine. Thus, the direct conversion of I2 → I− was achieved. This work provides a new idea for future research to design dual-mechanism cathode materials to suppress the shuttle effect of iodine. Iodine can adhere to carbon materials through surface adsorption [67,73]. Therefore, adsorption method as an important means was widely used in zinc iodine batteries [73–75]. The basic principle is to use the interaction between the adsorbent and the target substance, so that the target substance is aggregated on the surface of the adsorbent or in the pores. Dual immobilization strategy of iodine species using MPC and KB@CF separators inhibited the shuttle effect of iodide ions [34,76]. MPC as an iodine host enhanced the conductivity and stability of iodine. The KB separator acts as an effective barrier and absorber for iodine that may migrate to the anode side, improving iodine utilization. The prepared zinc iodine batteries have stable cycling capability, excellent multiplication performance and low-capacity decay rate. Numerous researchers have also used adsorption of porous carbon to inhibit the shuttle effect of iodide ions (Fig. 9g) [76]. Zinc citrate derived porous carbon as a protection layer was also proposed to guide the uniform deposition of zinc ions and inhibit the dissolution of iodine species and improve the reaction kinetics [77]. Compared with bromine and chlorine inserted into the graphite layer to form intercalation compounds, the surface adsorption of iodine can increase the area capacity of electrode, At the same time, it also prevents the volume expansion and structural change of the electrode material, thereby improving the cycle stability of battery. It has been shown that many substances other than porous carbon possess adsorption properties. For example, a novel porous polymer (CD-Si) was prepared for solid polymer electrolyte, which can simultaneously protect Zn anode from dendrite growth and inhibit the shuttle effect of polyiodide [78]. The use of a chalcogenide microcrystal with a zero-dimensional arrangement of octahedral chalcogenide units has also been proposed. The microcrystal has a high elemental iodine content, which provides reliable electrochemical activity for iodide ions through physical site-blocking and chemical adsorption of long-chain organic substrates. In addition, the presence of Sn (II) cations in the chalcogenide forms halogen bonds with iodide ions, mitigating the shuttle of iodide ions [79]. Nanomaterials with similar effects to porous carbon have also been used to inhibit the formation of undesirable intermediates during reactions by adsorption. And Li et al. have recently proposed to use the bis-ammonium chain of ODA as a host for halide guests (Fig. 9h) [80]. The electrochemically active halide bis-ammonium salts, including ODAI2, ODABr2 and ODABrI were synthesized by chemical constraint methods. The strong host–guest chemisorption interactions in the ODABr2 and ODAI2 electrodes are capable of triggering efficient electron transfer and suppressing the cross-diffusion of polyhalides [80]. 7 Summary and outlook In this review, we focused on summarizing the catalytic and redox effects that iodide ions have in ZBs. We elucidated the influence of iodine ions on the desolvation behavior and interfacial behavior of Zn2+. We also discussed the role of iodine redox pairs in enhancing other redox pairs, such as MnO2/Mn2+ redox pair and vanadium redox pair, to achieve high reversibility and capacity. In addition, the system analyzed the catalytic behavior of iodine in ZBs, synergistic reactions with other halide ions, and inhibition of shuttle behavior in high-performance zinc iodine batteries. However, there are still some aspects that need attention. For instance, the effect of the iodide ion concentration on its optimization of zinc ion battery performance is still unclear. The redox and catalytic behaviors of iodide ions have been relatively less studied. In addition, how to improve the stability of iodide ions during cycling process should be further explored. Therefore, future prospects for designing effective iodine electrochemical behaviors with are proposed, which will provide scientific guidance for the practical application of iodine-related aqueous ZBs. (1) The presence of iodide ions promotes the desolvation process of zinc ions, but it was found that the iodide ion concentration has a significant effect on the electrochemical performance of ZBs. Therefore, the concentration of iodide ions in the electrolyte should be rationally investigated and selected to maximize the battery performance. The concentration of iodine can affect the properties of the electrolyte, which in turn affects the behavior of zinc ions at the negative electrode. The concentration of iodine can also affect the reversibility of other redox pairs. If the concentration is too high, it will occupy the reaction surface and accumulate irreversible iodine. If the concentration of iodine is too low, it will be difficult to maintain adequate redox processes. The charge–discharge response of the battery will be limited. The discharge capacity and energy density of the battery are affected. Therefore, the electrochemical behavior of iodine chemistry was further studied by means of electrochemical impedance, Tafel slope curve and data analysis when appropriate iodine concentration was added. (2) The redox and catalytic behaviors related to iodine reactions present very important. There are many factors to consider when coupling redox pairs with other redox pairs, such as the type of energy storage mechanism in cathode electrode materials and the type of electrolyte. It is worth noting that the selection of electrolyte needs to consider the solubility and stability of iodine. Catalytic behaviors are widely studied in iodine chemistry, but the choice of catalyst is crucial. It should focus on exploring carrier materials with better adsorption properties to study the effect of catalytic processes of iodide ions on battery performance. In addition, evaluating the stability of catalysts still needs to consider factors such as the concentration of iodine ions and the surface capacity of the electrode, which are easily overlooked in conventional research. (3) How to improve the stability of iodide ions during cycling process should be further explored. Due to the fact that iodine ions usually dissolve in electrolytes, components that affect their stability include cathode carriers, Zn anode, electrolytes, and separators. These factors require scientific design to promote reversible reactions of iodine ions. Normally, the stability of iodine chemistry is evaluated at very low area capacity (below 0.4mAh cm−2). However, it does not meet the requirements of practical applications and needs to be evaluated at higher area capacity. It is best for research groups to establish a standard for iodine loading or area capacity in order to improve the universal reference value of research results. coredata.dc:description: Iodine is widely used in aqueous zinc batteries (ZBs) due to its abundant resources, low cost, and active redox reactions. In addition to the active material in zinc-iodine batteries, iodine also plays an important role in other ZBs, such as regulating the electrochemical behavior of zinc ions, promoting the reaction kinetic and reversibility of other redox pairs, catalytic behaviors related to iodine reactions, coupling with other halogen ions, shuttle behaviors of polyiodides, etc. However, there is currently a lack of comprehensive discussion on these aspects. Here, this review provides a comprehensive overview of the electrochemical behaviors of iodide in the aqueous ZBs. The effect of iodine ions on the Zn2+ desolvation behaviors and the interfacial behaviors of Zn anode was summarized. Iodine redox pairs boosting other redox pairs, such as MnO2/Mn2+ redox pair and vanadium redox pair to obtain high reversibility and capacity was also discussed. Moreover, the catalytic behaviors related to iodine reactions in aqueous ZBs, synergistic reaction with other halogen ions and suppression of shuttle behaviors for high performance zinc-iodine batteries were systematically analyzed. Finally, future prospects for designing effective iodine electrochemical behaviors with practicability are proposed, which will provide scientific guidance for the practical application of iodine-related aqueous ZBs.
